Eversmann.Action: Jolts from the sight of unarmed civilians being shot, urgently alerts others to the violence.
Notices and promptly reports unarmed civilians being shot during the mission, showing situational awareness and communication.
Blows whistle to stop firing and checks weapons, showing responsibility and care for safety.
Responds blankly to Blackburn's report and redirects him to another officer, showing a neutral, professional demeanor without warmth.
Smirks and allows Grimes to leave Blackburn with him, indicating a friendly and somewhat trusting attitude.
Blows whistle to cease fire and commands soldiers to check weapons, demonstrating control and attention to safety.
Responds blankly and somewhat dismissively to Blackburn's report, showing a lack of warmth or engagement.
Redirects Blackburn to report to Lieutenant Beales, correctly enforcing chain of command.
Smirks and allows Grimes to leave Blackburn with him without objection, showing confidence in handling the situation.
Expresses respect for the local Somali people despite their hardships.
Shows idealism and a sincere belief in the mission to help the Somali people.
Shows thoughtful reflection on the mission and the local people, expressing respect and a sense of purpose rather than mere prejudice or indifference.
Engages in a calm, reasoned discussion about the mission's goals and the situation in Somalia, demonstrating understanding and commitment.
Moves closer to check on Beales during his seizure, showing concern.
Accepts responsibility for Beales' chalk without complaint, despite feeling anxious.
Carefully chooses his words when questioned, showing thoughtfulness and awareness.
Moves closer to assess Beales' medical emergency, showing initiative and concern.
Accepts responsibility for the chalk without objection, indicating willingness to lead despite anxiety.
Feels anxious about new responsibility, showing self-doubt.
Accepts the responsibility given by Steele and confidently states 'Rangers are the way, Sir.'
Pauses to consider the enormity of the duty he's just been given, showing awareness and reflection.
Swallows nervously and checks others' reactions during tense briefing.
Observes quietly from inside the tent while others express concern openly.
Swallows nervously but checks others' reactions before proceeding.
Observes the conversation and gathers information quietly without interrupting.
Tells Smith the time and place of the mission when asked, and asks Smith to back him up and keep sharp.
Assigns Grimes a role and encourages the team with sincere, motivating words emphasizing their elite status and seriousness.
Acknowledges his inexperience as a Chalk leader openly but maintains confidence and reassurance for the team.
Assigns Grimes a clear, manageable task and motivates the team with confidence despite it being his first time as Chalk leader.
Acknowledges his inexperience openly but uses it to rally the team and maintain morale.
Exhales heavily after giving orders, possibly indicating stress or uncertainty.
Gives practical, straightforward advice to Grimes about shooting in the same direction as others.
Observes Blackburn's nervousness quietly, without judgment or comment.
Reminds Grimes to shoot in the same direction as everyone else when shooting.
Pats Blackburn on the shoulder after admitting neither has shot at anyone before.
Asks Blackburn if he has ever shot at anyone before and admits he hasn't either, showing honesty and openness.
Pats Blackburn on the shoulder to encourage him, demonstrating leadership and confidence.
No indication of prior combat experience or expertise is shown; admits to inexperience.
Leans against a wall next to Hoot, shares a quiet moment reflecting on the situation and expresses a desire to do things right today.
Expresses a desire to do the mission right today, showing focus and conscientiousness.
Leans silently against a wall, appearing contemplative and somewhat uneasy about the situation.
Looks after General Garrison with concern when he unexpectedly comes out to wish the men well.
Dismisses Blackburn and Grimes' question about his concern with a brief 'Nothing.'
Encourages his men loudly and clearly to go in during a dangerous fast rope insertion, showing leadership and concern for their readiness.
Commands his men decisively to fast rope into a dangerous, dusty combat zone despite incoming fire, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Encourages Blackburn with 'Go Blackburn, go!'
Encourages Blackburn to move quickly and decisively during a dangerous situation.
Maintains situational awareness by spotting an incoming RPG while coordinating the team.
Shouts warnings to pilot and Blackburn about incoming RPG, showing concern for others' safety.
Dives out after Blackburn who fell, showing immediate concern and willingness to help.
Checks on Blackburn's condition and calls for medic, demonstrating care and responsibility.
Shouts warning 'RPG!' to pilot and Blackburn, helping the Black Hawk avoid the rocket.
Dives out after Blackburn who fell, grabbing the rope and fast-roping down to reach him.
Checks Blackburn immediately after landing and calls for the medic, showing situational awareness and concern.
Appears momentarily startled when medic Schmid suddenly appears behind him.
Urgently calls for help to get the wounded Blackburn out of danger, showing concern for his comrade's safety.
Shouts into the radio repeatedly despite communication difficulties, demonstrating persistence and care for his team.
Attempts to communicate urgently with Captain Steele despite radio issues, maintaining situational awareness and command presence.
Shouts into walkie-talkie to relay critical information about a wounded man and the situation under fire.
Shows frustration and urgency but remains focused on coordinating evacuation under heavy fire.
Does not resolve the radio communication problem himself, relying on others and continuing to shout, which may indicate limited technical troubleshooting.
Notices incoming Little Bird and reacts quickly to hot casings hitting him, pulling a casing out of his flak jacket.
Reassures Nelson by telling him he is dependable when assigning him to hold the corner.
Takes initiative to organize his men and move toward the crash site despite unclear orders.
Attempts to locate the crash site despite poor visibility and unclear instructions.
Takes initiative to organize his men and move toward the crash site on foot when radio communication fails.
Assigns Nelson to hold the corner and exit with the Humvees, showing trust in his dependability.
Takes charge and leads his chalk under heavy fire, encouraging his team with commands like 'Let's go!' and 'Go!'
Leaves Nelson behind because Nelson is 'dependable,' implying trust in his reliability
Leads his chalk confidently under heavy fire, coordinating movement and returning fire effectively.
Commands 'Go!' decisively during an ambush, maintaining momentum despite danger.
Calls out to Galentine to check if he is okay after Galentine drops his weapon while seeking cover.
Observes Galentine about to risk running back into the street to retrieve his weapon, indicating concern for his safety.
Notices enemy rifle tip and Galentine's risky move to retrieve weapon in open street, indicating situational awareness.
Calls out to Galentine to check if he is okay, showing concern and leadership under fire.
Warns Galentine not to run out into the street, showing concern for his safety.
Steps into the street to cover Galentine by firing at the enemy, risking his own safety to protect a comrade.
Steps into the street under fire to cover Galentine, firing at the enemy to protect his teammate.
Fires nearly nonstop during chaotic combat, effectively supporting the groupâ€™s movement.
Checks on Galentine's condition and coordinates covering fire for his team.
Leads his men charging into heavy fire to reach the crash site, showing concern for wounded comrades.
Leads his men confidently through heavy enemy fire toward the crash site, coordinating covering fire and advancing despite danger.
Quickly assesses the situation at the crash site, communicates effectively with his team about casualties and urgency to evacuate.
Charges toward the downed chopper under heavy fire, showing courage but potentially exposing himself to unnecessary risk.
Urgently calls for medivac for wounded and dead pilots, coordinates perimeter setup with Di Tomasso, communicates clearly under fire.
Focuses on tactical commands and mission objectives without evident personal interaction or emotional expression.
Sprints from the downed chopper under fire, quickly joins comrades in a defensive position.
Communicates clearly and promptly over radio to coordinate perimeter setup and request medivac.
Directs Di Tomasso to take the Southeast border and set up a perimeter despite heavy enemy fire.
Persistently requests medivac and information about reinforcements, showing situational awareness.
Runs for cover behind upended trucks and promptly communicates clearly with team members about the situation.
Acknowledges orders and confirms understanding with concise radio communication.
Glances over at Galentine, noticing his ghostly white face and listens attentively to the radio.
Focuses on the radio communication and the faces of his chalk, showing concern and attentiveness.
Listens attentively to radio communications and quickly processes the critical information about the downed helicopter.
Appears momentarily startled or confused ('What?') before fully grasping the situation.
Recognizes the significance of the radio call about another downed Black Hawk and immediately processes the situation with his men.
Joins Grimes to go with Delta on a dangerous mission despite the evident fear and uncertainty among the men.
No direct action or statement in this excerpt indicating poor understanding or failure.
Commands his men firmly to regroup and evacuate under heavy fire, showing concern for their safety.
Swears under his breath as bullets explode overhead, indicating stress but no loss of composure or disregard for others.
Commands his men assertively under heavy fire, demanding the return of Nelson and Twombly, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Swears under his breath as bullets explode overhead, indicating stress but continuing to lead effectively.
Decides to get back to the stronghold to regroup, showing tactical prudence under pressure.
Sets up a perimeter around Wolcott's crash site, coordinates positions of friendly forces.
Sets up a perimeter around Wolcott's crash site, indicating tactical awareness and leadership.
Coordinates with adjacent units and casualty collection points, showing situational understanding and communication.
No direct actions or statements by Eversmann in this excerpt to evaluate competence.
No direct actions or statements by Eversmann in this excerpt; focus is on Durant, Shughart, and Gordon.
Addresses his men calmly, looks each in the eye, acknowledges their fear, and rallies them with encouragement and clear instructions.
Maintains focus on mission and safety, urging ammo conservation and disciplined shooting, showing care for his men's survival.
Takes charge of the situation by organizing men to hold the perimeter and strongpoint, giving clear, calm orders to conserve ammo and focus fire.
Maintains morale and focus among scared and confused men by inspiring confidence and unity with motivational commands.
Communicates clearly and cooperatively with Sanderson to coordinate movements and avoid friendly fire.
Listens attentively to the evening prayer along with others, showing shared human experience and respect.
Communicates clearly and effectively over radio with Sanderson, giving precise tactical information and warnings about enemy positions.
Positions his men strategically outside the Alamo building, showing situational awareness and planning.
Quietly instructs his men to hold fire to the east, showing concern for their safety and tactical awareness.
Asks Yurek where he has been and if he is okay, showing care and concern for his men.
Quietly orders his men to hold fire to the east, demonstrating control and situational awareness.
Responds promptly to Yurek's call, asks about their status and location, showing communication and leadership.
Encourages and coordinates covering fire to protect teammates during a dangerous crossing.
Expresses frustration and concern when Twombly is hit, showing emotional involvement.
Runs past injured Twombly to help Smith, then drags Smith to safety under fire.
Reassures Smith repeatedly while he is injured, showing care and support.
Watches and coordinates covering fire effectively, radios back to confirm support, and orders movement decisively.
Fails to warn Twombly of the imminent threat despite seeing Somalis aiming, resulting in Twombly being hit.
Acts quickly and skillfully under fire to drag wounded Smith to safety and assist in immediate care.
Urgently calls for medivac and medical supplies, attempts to treat Smith's severe wound despite difficulty.
Maintains focus on helping wounded comrade under extreme pressure.
Rips Smith's pant leg despite arterial spray, quickly applies Curlex gauze to a severe wound under pressure.
Recognizes the severity of Smith's injury and immediately calls for medivac and Captain Steele.
Presses gauze into a wound that is too severe to be easily controlled, showing persistence and skill under stress.
Reassures wounded Smith by saying 'Yeah. It's gonna be all right, it's gonna be okay.'
Calmly reassures the wounded Smith despite the dire situation and lack of immediate medical support.
Accepts the negative medivac decision without protest and focuses on immediate care.
Willingly assists Doc Schmid in a critical medical procedure to save Smith's life.
Agrees to assist Doc Schmid in a critical medical procedure involving clamping a femoral artery to stop bleeding.
Responds promptly and confidently to Schmid's request for help without hesitation.
Nods ready to assist Schmid during a painful medical procedure, holds the wound open as instructed, communicates clearly about the artery slipping and the clamp.
Nods ready to assist Schmid in a critical medical procedure, holds clamps and attempts to control bleeding under pressure.
Struggles to keep artery clamped as it slips away, indicating difficulty in maintaining control during the procedure.
Reassures Smith by saying 'Yeah, man. We got it.' after a tense medical moment.
Holds the wound and keeps calm under pressure while Schmid struggles to find the artery.
Keeps the clamp ready but does not intervene prematurely, allowing Schmid to attempt the procedure.
Assures Smith that the wound is fixed despite the difficulty and Schmid's frustration.
Calls out 'Incoming!' and runs forward despite incoming rounds shaking the building.
Checks on the well-being of his team immediately after a blast.
Comforts and reassures Smith who is panicking and near death, telling him he did well and encouraging him to be proud.
Promises to tell Smith's parents he fought well, offering emotional support and hope.
Keeps calm and attentive to Smith's needs, showing sincere concern and presence.
Calms and reassures a panicked, injured soldier (Smith) by reminding him of his training and accomplishments, showing emotional control and leadership under stress.
Keeps watch over Smith and Twombly, providing support and hope while waiting for rescue, demonstrating situational awareness and care.
Encourages Smith to hold on and reassures him repeatedly with 'This is nothin''.
Grips Smith's bloodstained hand and nods, showing support and connection in a dire moment.
Expresses despair with 'Oh, God.' after failed CPR, showing emotional vulnerability and sincerity.
Questions Hoot about taking ammo from the fallen soldier, indicating concern and respect for Smith's belongings.
Mentions that medivac should have been sent, showing care and frustration about the situation.
Encourages Smith to hold on and stay strong despite dire circumstances, showing leadership and emotional resilience.
Attempts to intervene and stop Schmid during CPR, possibly indicating emotional overwhelm or lack of medical knowledge.
Accepts the reality of the situation and reflects on the lack of medivac support, showing situational awareness.
Expresses frustration about medivac not arriving, which may indicate a focus on what could have been done rather than adapting to current circumstances.
Expresses regret over Smith's death and the consequences of Blackburn falling, showing concern for his men and the situation.
Commands his men decisively under fire, focusing on their defense and safety.
Takes command under fire by ordering 'I need four guns on this corner, now!'
Acknowledges the death of Smith and the consequences but does not dwell on blame, showing situational awareness.
Glances up at Hoot when praised, indicating receptiveness to leadership and confidence.
Communicates clearly with Wood under chaotic conditions ('This is Two Five. I can see you, you're right above me.')
Asks for cover fire and relies on teammates to help him place the strobe under fire.
Takes initiative to mark the target despite danger, showing trust in his team and willingness to cooperate.
Attempts to mark the target with a strobe but the first one fails to fire; quickly adapts by gathering more IR strobes and prepares to try again.
Requests cover fire from his team before exposing himself to enemy fire to place the strobe, demonstrating tactical awareness and coordination.
Runs into heavy enemy fire to place the strobe on the roof, showing courage and commitment to the mission despite high risk.
Leaps inside to safety under heavy fire, maintains position despite RPG and intense enemy fire.
Communicates situational awareness with urgency ('Shit!') but continues to hold position and coordinate with support.
Encourages his men by announcing the convoy's arrival, sharing relief with them.
Responds respectfully and warmly to Colonel McKnight, smiling and shaking his hand.
Acknowledges radio communication promptly and confidently, signaling readiness and situational awareness.
Keeps his men calm and reassured by announcing the convoy's arrival, demonstrating leadership and composure under pressure.
Maintains defensive position with his team, effectively returning fire and managing limited resources.
Responds quickly to Kurth's call of being out of ammo, indicating good communication and situational control.
Shows positive morale and confidence by smiling when greeted by Colonel McKnight, reflecting good interpersonal skills and morale management.
Carries Smith's body with Doc Schmid out into the night and loads it into an APC, while remaining vigilant and covering the team.
Carries Smith's body out into the night with Doc Schmid, maintaining vigilance and covering the team by watching rooftops and windows.
Attempts to get aboard the vehicles to cover and protect the retreating soldiers, runs after the convoy despite no space being available.
Does not push or force his way onto the vehicles when told there is no room, instead follows on foot with others.
Attempts to get aboard the convoy vehicles to evacuate but finds no space as all vehicles are full and no one stops for them.
Continues to cover the retreat of the Mountain soldiers and Rangers, showing situational awareness and commitment despite limited options.
Follows the convoy on foot after failing to get on vehicles, demonstrating persistence but limited ability to influence the situation.
Calls out to Sanderson that he is out of ammo, signaling honesty and reliance on teammates.
Communicates clearly and promptly that he is out of ammo to Sanderson during intense combat.
Leads the group running into the stadium seeking safety, showing concern for survival and well-being of his men.
Staggers forward into the medical area, indicating perseverance and trust in the care provided.
Leads the group running through dangerous conditions to reach the safety of the soccer stadium, successfully making it inside despite chaos and injury.
Staggers forward inside the medical area, showing signs of physical strain but continuing to move with purpose.
Approaches Hoot calmly and resupplies himself after Hoot, showing understanding of Hoot's motivations and respecting his wishes.
Watches Hoot walk away without intervening when Hoot insists on going alone, respecting his autonomy.
Calmly and efficiently resupplies himself after observing Hoot, showing readiness and composure.
Questions Hoot incredulously about going back in despite the danger, indicating some hesitation or lack of full confidence.
Laughs at the idea of being a hero, showing humility and sincerity.
Touches Smith's chest gently, making a personal connection with a wounded comrade.
Promises to talk to Smith's parents, showing care and responsibility.
Reflects on personal change and the impact of war, showing emotional openness.
Maintains composure and reflects thoughtfully on the meaning of heroism and his experience after combat, showing emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Engages in a meaningful, calm conversation with a wounded comrade, demonstrating presence of mind and empathy in a difficult situation.
Does not display any direct tactical or operational decisions or actions in this excerpt, focusing instead on internal reflection and emotional processing.
